fr:mainmatter.fr:p: An affine scheme is a locally ringed space of the form \operatorname {Spec}(R) for some commutative ring R.

Consider the affine scheme X = \operatorname {Spec} \mathbb {C}[x, y]/(y^2 - x^3) \simeq \operatorname {Spec} \mathbb {C}[t^2, t^3], which is a degenerate cubic curve. We can remove the point (1,1), giving the open U = D(x-1) \cup D(y-1). We claim that U is an affine subscheme but it is not of the form D(f).

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: We first prove it is not distinguished. Suppose U = D(f), we can choose a representative of f in \mathbb {C}[x, y]. Now substituting x \mapsto t^2, y \mapsto t^3, we need f(t^2, t^3) to vanish only at t = 1. Hence this is a polynomial \lambda (t - 1)^n. But this is impossible since it has a linear term, which cannot be produced by t^2 and t^3.

Now we need to show U is affine. The coordinate ring is actually given by the subring R of \mathbb {C}[t, (t-1)^{-1}] such that the derivative at zero is zero, which can be verified by gluing. By we have a canonical map U \to \operatorname {Spec} R. Now restricting to the open D(t^2 - 1) and D(t^3 - 1) respectively, the two schemes are affine. By verifying the isomorphism of global sections, we see that they are isomorphic. Note that (t^3 - 1) \cdot \frac {t^2}{t - 1} - (t^2 - 1) \cdot \left (\frac {t^3}{t - 1} + 1\right ) = 1. So these cover \operatorname {Spec} R (this is where it differs from ), and we have our isomorphism.
The open subscheme of \mathbb {A}_{\mathbb {C}}^2 = \operatorname {Spec} \mathbb {C}[x, y] given by removing the origin, or equivalently the open D(x) \cup D(y), is not affine.

We just need to prove the affinification is not an isomorphism. Consider the global sections of the structure sheaf, which comes from the pullback of \mathbb {C}[x, y, x^{-1}] and \mathbb {C}[x, y, y^{-1}] over \mathbb {C}[x, y, x^{-1}, y^{-1}]. The result is simply \mathbb {C}[x, y]. We can compute that the affinification map is the inclusion map into \mathbb {A}_{\mathbb {C}}^2. This cannot be an isomorphism because the underlying space is different.

Given a scheme S, we can produce a best affine approximation S \to S' for it. This serves as the adjoint unit of the adjunction of global section and \operatorname {Spec}. Here we give a construction from the ground up.

We define S' = \operatorname {Spec} \Gamma (\top , \mathscr {O}_X). For the map S \to S', we define the preimage of the distinguished open D(f) to be the non-vanishing open of f \in \Gamma (\top , \mathscr {O}_X), which is defined on each affine subscheme as the distinguished open of f. This is obviously continuous. We can then pull back a section f/g by considering them as an element of \Gamma (\top , \mathscr {O}_X) and restricting them.
A scheme is affine iff the affinification is an isomorphism. This is a formal consequence that affine schemes form a full subcategory of schemes.

We define the scheme \mathbf {G}_{m} as \operatorname {Spec} \mathbb {Z}[x, x^{-1}]. It can be characterized by the points \hom (\mathbf {G}_{m}, \operatorname {Spec} R) = R^\times being the units of R. This scheme has a group structure. Since it is affine, 1 \to \mathbf {G}_{m} is given by the ring homomorphism \mathbb {Z}[x, x^{-1}] \to \mathbb Z sending x to 1. The product map is given by a ring homomorphism \mathbb {Z}[x, x^{-1}] \otimes \mathbb {Z}[y, y^{-1}] \to \mathbb {Z}[z, z^{-1}] (where we renamed the variables for clarity) sending x \otimes y to z. The inverse map \mathbb {Z}[x, x^{-1}] \to \mathbb {Z}[x, x^{-1}] sends x to x^{-1}.
The intersections of two affine subschemes \operatorname {Spec}(R_1), \operatorname {Spec}(R_2) \hookrightarrow X can be covered by affine schemes distinguished in both of them.

We just need to cover each point of the intersection. Suppose a point in the intersection is given by a prime ideal \mathfrak {p} of R_1. We can pick a distinguished open D(f) of \operatorname {Spec}(R_2) contained in the intersection and containing \mathfrak {p}, and a distinguished open D(g) of \operatorname {Spec}(R_1) contained in D(f) and containing \mathfrak {p}. Now we prove that D(g) is a distinguished open in \operatorname {Spec}(R_2).

It suffices to prove that D(g) is a distinguished open in \operatorname {Spec}(R_2 [f^{-1}]), since this would imply the existence of an element g'/f^{n} \in R_2[f^{-1}], and we can take D(g') \cap D(f) = D(g' f) in \operatorname {Spec}(R_2). Now there is an inclusion map \operatorname {Spec}(R_2[f^{-1}]) \to \operatorname {Spec}(R_1), which amounts to a ring homomorphism \varphi by . In this case, D(\varphi (g)) is the required distinguished open, since \varphi ^{-1}D(u) is equal to D(\varphi (u)) in \operatorname {Spec}(R_2 [f^{-1}]).

Morphism of affine schemes are in natural bijection with ring homomorphisms in the opposite direction. In other words, there is a fully faithful embedding \mathsf {CRing}^\textrm {op} \to \mathsf {Sch}.

Given two rings R, S, a ring homomorphism \varphi : S \to R naturally induces a map of distinguished opens f \mapsto \varphi (f). This is a continuous map \operatorname {Spec}(R) \to \operatorname {Spec}(S), because \varphi preserves \operatorname {lcm} and \gcd on radical ideals. For the structure sheaf, we can use the distinguished basis, thus we need to supply a ring homomorphism \Gamma (D(s), \mathscr {O}_{\operatorname {Spec}(S)}) \to \Gamma (D(r), \mathscr {O}_{\operatorname {Spec}(R)}) whenever D(r) \subseteq \varphi ^{-1}D(s) = D(\varphi (s)). This is just a homomorphism S[s^{-1}] \to R[r^{-1}], which is obvious because \varphi (s) must be invertible in R[r^{-1}].

We need to prove our map is local. Using the characterization on stalks, we just need to verify that S_{\varphi ^{-1}(\mathfrak {p})} \to R_{\mathfrak {p}} reflects invertibility. This is true by construction. Hence we have a map \hom _{\mathsf {CRing}}(S, R) \to \hom _{\mathsf {Sch}}(\operatorname {Spec}(R), \operatorname {Spec}(S)).
A scheme is a locally ringed space with an open covering on which the space is isomorphic to affine schemes.
Given a ringed space, i.e. a space X with a sheaf of rings \mathscr {O}, it is said to be locally ringed iff the following conditions hold.

fr:ul.fr:li: Suppose f + g \in \Gamma (U, \mathscr {O}) is invertible, then we can cover U with two open sets such that f and g are invertible when restricted respectively.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: This can be unified as one condition: If a finite sum in \Gamma (U, \mathscr {O}) is invertible, then each summand is invertible when restricted to an open, which jointly covers U.
